revision.text:
{{Other people||Phil Adams (disambiguation){{!}}Phil Adams}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Phillip Adams | post-nominals = {{Post-nominals|size=100|country=AUS|AO|FAHA}} {{Post-nominals|size=100|country=UK|FRSA}} | image = Phillip Adams.jpg | alt = | caption = Adams speaking at the
2010 Global Atheist Convention | birth_name = Phillip Andrew Hedley Adams | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1939|07|12}} | birth_place = [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]], Victoria | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | other_names = | known_for = Revival of Australian cinema;
Public intellectualism | occupation = Film producer; journalist; broadcaster; former advertising executive | spouse = Rosemary Fawcett (dis.)
[[Patrice Newell]] | residence = [[Hunter Region|Hunter Valley]], [[New South Wales]] | religion = }} '''Phillip Andrew Hedley Adams''' [[Order of Australia|AO]] [[Australian Academy of the Humanities|FAHA]] [[Royal Society of Arts|FRSA]] (born 12 July 1939) is an Australian [[Humanism|humanist]], social commentator, broadcaster, public intellectual and farmer. He hosts ''[[Late Night Live]]'', an [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) program on [[ABC Radio National|Radio National]] four nights a week. He also writes a weekly column for ''[[The Weekend Australian]]''. Adams has had careers in advertising and film production and has served on many non-profit boards including [[Greenpeace Australia]], [[Ausflag]], [[Care Australia]], [[Film Victoria]], [[National Museum of Australia]], both the [[Adelaide Festival of Ideas|Adelaide]] and [[Ideas Festival|Brisbane]] festivals of ideas, the Montsalvat Arts Society and the [[Don Dunstan#Legacy|Don Dunstan Foundation]]. Adams has been appointed both a member and subsequently an officer of the [[Order of Australia]]; and he has received numerous awards including five honorary doctorates from Australian universities; Republican of the Year 2005; the Senior ANZAC Fellowship; the Australian Humanist of the Year, the [[Golden Lion]] at Cannes; the Longford Award; a [[Walkley Award]]; and the Henry Lawson Australian Arts Award. In 1997 the [[International Astronomical Union]] named a minor planet orbiting the sun between Mars and Jupiter after him. A [[National Trust of Australia|National Trust]] poll elected him one of Australia's 100 [[Australian Living Treasures|national living treasures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.au/nsw/NationalLivingTreasures|title=National Living Treasures|publisher=[[National Trust of Australia]]|date=2012|accessdate=23 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129093613/http://www.nationaltrust.org.au/nsw/NationalLivingTreasures|archivedate=29 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Early years== Adams was born in [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]], Victoria, the only child of [[Congregational Church]] minister, the Reverend Charles Adams. His childhood was anything but idyllic and his parents separated when he was young. Interviewed in 2006, Adams said that:{{cite interview|last=Adams|first=Phillip|interviewer=[[Richard Fidler]]|title=Broadcaster Phillip Adams in conversation with Richard Fidler|type=Radio interview|url=http://www.abc.net.au/queensland/conversations/stories/s1690728.htm|format=transcript and streaming audio|work=The Backyard|publisher=[[ABC Radio National]]|location=Australia|date=19 July 2006|page= |pages= |access-date=23 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101095832/http://www.abc.net.au/queensland/conversations/stories/s1690728.htm|archive-date=2007-11-01|dead-url=yes|quote=}}
My first memories were my mother... absolutely dependent on the begging bowl – that little round dish with a piece of cloth at the bottom where parishioners would put a couple of bob. When dad went off to the war, I was taken up by my grandparents... and lived on a dirt-poor farm... I lived in penury for the first 10, 15 years of my life. ... Mother dumped [my father] in favour of a rather sleazy businessman ... a sociopath who tried to murder me ... I spent my latter part of my childhood trying to protect my mother from this psycho.
Of his education he has said: "I was forced to leave school before completing my secondary education and the only job I could get was working in advertising." Adams joined the [[Australian Communist Party]]{{cite interview|last=Adams|first=Phillip|interviewer=[[Richard Fidler]]|title=Phillip Adams|type=Radio interview|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2006/09/14/1740844.htm|format=transcript and streaming audio|work=Conversations with Richard Fidler|publisher=[[ABC Local Radio]]|location=Australia|date=14 September 2006|page= |pages= |access-date=23 December 2014|quote=}} at age 16, whilst employed in advertising, but left at age 19. He has often compared dogmatic belief in communism to dogmatic belief in [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} ==Career== Adams began his advertising career with [[Foote Cone & Belding]] and, later, with Brian Monahan and Lyle Dayman, became a partner in the agency Monahan Dayman Adams. They took that company to a successful public listing and Adams became a millionaire in the process.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He developed successful campaigns such as ''[[Life. Be in it.]]'',{{cite web|title=Animation cel of 'Norm' from the 'Life. Be in it' campaign, 1993 – 1994|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=12209&search=alexander&images=&c=1&s=|work=Powerhouse Museum Collection Search 2.53|format=Acetate, paper, cardboard|author1=Stitt, Alexander|author2=Adams, Phillip|location=South Yarra, Victoria, Australia|date=1993–1994|publisher=[[Powerhouse Museum]], Sydney}} ''[[Slip-Slop-Slap|Slip, Slop, Slap]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sunsmart.com.au/browse.asp?ContainerID=1808|title=Page Not Found|first=SunSmart|last=Victoria|website=SunSmart}} ''Break down the Barriers'', ''Guess whose mum's got a Whirlpool'' and ''Watch the big men fly for a Herbert Adams Pie'', working with talent such as [[Fred Schepisi]], Alex Stitt, [[Peter Best (composer)|Peter Best]], [[Robyn Archer]] and Mimmo Cozzolino. Adams left the advertising industry in the 1980s. Monahan Dayman Adams purchased the successful Sydney agency [[Mojo (advertising)|MoJo]] in 1987 and carried on as MojoMDA. Its lineage can today be traced to Publicis Mojo, an Australian subsidiary of the French [[multinational corporation|multinational]] advertising and communications company holding [[Publicis Groupe]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He wrote regular columns for ''[[The Age]]'' and ''[[The Bulletin]]''. He currently writes a weekly column for ''The Australian''. ===Film work=== Adams played a key role in the revival of the [[Cinema of Australia|Australian film industry]] during the 1970s.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/03/06/1046826480126.html?oneclick=true|location=Melbourne|work=[[The Age]]|date=7 March 2003|accessdate=23 December 2014|title=Bazza turns 30}} He was the author of a 1969 report{{cite web|url=http://www.tabula-rasa.info/AusHorror/OzHorrorFilms4.html|title=A Brief History of the Film Industry in Australia and New Zealand|work=Killer Koalas: Australian (and New Zealand) Horror Films|format=Appendix|author=Hood, Robert|date=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} which led to legislation by Prime Minister [[John Gorton]] in 1970 for an Australian Film and Television Development Corporation (later the [[Australian Film Commission]]) and the Experimental Film Fund. Together with [[Barry Jones (Australian politician)|Barry Jones]], Adams was a motivating force behind the [[Australian Film Television and Radio School]] which was established under the [[Whitlam|Whitlam government]].{{cite web|url=http://screenforever.org.au/program/phillip-adams-ao/|title=Phillip Adams AO|work=Screen Forever|publisher=Screen Producers Australia|date=November 2014|accessdate=23 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223132555/http://screenforever.org.au/program/phillip-adams-ao/|archivedate=23 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} Adams played a key role in the development of the [[South Australian Film Corporation]], which was created in 1972 and became a model for similar bodies in other Australian states; and in the establishment of the [[Australia Council]] and the [[Australian Film Development Corporation]], later known as the Australian Film Commission, the [[Film Finance Corporation Australia]], and [[Screen Australia]]. As head of delegation to the [[Cannes Film Festival]], Adams signed Australia's first co-production agreements with France and the UK. He was Chairman of the [[Australian Film Institute]], the Film and Television Board of the Australia Council, the Australian Film Commission, and Film Australia. He helped establish the Australian Caption Service, which provides services for hearing-impaired television viewers – and the Travelling Film Festival to take quality films into rural areas.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} In the 1960s Adams co-wrote, co-produced and co-directed (as well as serving as cinematographer for) his first feature film ''[[Jack and Jill: A Postscript]]'' (1969); the first feature to win the [[Australian Film Institute Award|AFI Award]],{{cite web|url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/23/carlton-australian-revival.html|author=Hodson, Bruce|title=The Carlton Ripple and the Australian Film Revival|work=Screening the Past|date=|accessdate=15 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218063047/http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/23/carlton-australian-revival.html|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} and the first Australian film to win the Grand Prix at an international festival. Adams produced or co-produced other features including the critically panned but hugely popular film adaptation of Barry Humphries' ''[[The Adventures of Barry McKenzie]]'', directed by [[Bruce Beresford]], which became the most successful Australian film ever made up to that time. Other films include ''[[The Naked Bunyip]]'', ''[[Don's Party]]'', ''[[The Getting of Wisdom (film)|The Getting of Wisdom]]'', ''Lonely Hearts'', ''[[We of the Never Never]]'', ''[[Grendel Grendel Grendel]]'', ''Fighting Back'', ''Hearts and Minds'' and ''[[Abra Cadabra (1983 film)|Abra Cadabra]]''. ===Broadcasting=== Adams initially presented a late-night program on Sydney commercial radio station [[2UE]] during the late 1980s and early 1990s before succeeding [[Virginia Bell]] in 1991 at ABC Radio National's ''Late Night Live'', a magazine{{endash}}style program that broadcasts analysis of current events to Australian and international politics, science, philosophy and culture. ''Late Night Live'' is broadcast across Australia on ABC Radio National, as well as on [[Radio Australia]] and the Internet. The program is broadcast live from 22:00 [[Australian Time|AEST]]/[[Australian Daylight Saving Time|ADST]] and is repeated the following day at 16:00 AEST/ADST.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/latenightlive/|work=ABC Radio National|title=About us: Late Night Live|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} A serious discussion of world issues, the program is tempered with Adams' gentle and ironic humour.{{cite book|author=Luker, Philip|title=Phillip Adams: The Ideas Man – A Life Revealed|page=206|date=20 April 2011|publisher=JoJo Publishing|isbn=978-0-9870734-6-4}} Regular contributors include [[Bruce Shapiro]] and [[Beatrix Campbell]]. At times, Adams refers [[tongue-in-cheek]] to his listeners as "the listener" or "Gladys", as though he had only one listener; he also refers to listeners collectively as "Gladdies". In more recent years, Adams has begun introducing the show saying "Good evening Gladdies and Poddies", in reference to the show's growing [[podcast]] listener base. The current theme music is a short extract from [[Elena Kats-Chernin]]'s ''[[Wild Swans (ballet)|Wild Swans Concert Suite]]'', performed by the [[Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra]] with [[soprano]] [[Jane Sheldon]], chosen in 2010. From 2007 to 2010, the theme music was Kats-Chernin's "Russian Rag", which Adams humorously refers to as "The Waltz of the Wombat". The previous music was [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s [[Keyboard concertos by Johann Sebastian Bach#Concerto in C minor, BWV 1060|Concerto for oboe, violin and orchestra in C minor, BWV 1060]]: III. ''Allegro''. ===Other work=== Adams was the foundation chairman of the Commission for the Future, established by the [[Hawke government]] to build bridges between science and the community. In 1988 the Commission won a major United Nations award for educating Australia on the issue of greenhouse and [[climate change]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He chaired the [[National Australia Day Council]]; whose principal task was to choose the Australian of the Year. He also chaired the Advisory Board for the Centre of the Mind at the [[University of Sydney]] and the [[Australia National University]] and has been a board member of Greenpeace Australia, CARE Australia, the National Museum of Australia, The Australian Centre for Social Innovation, the [[Adelaide Festival of Ideas]] and Brisbane's [[Ideas Festival]]. He was co-founder of the [[Australian Skeptics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.celebrityspeakers.com.au/media-speakers/phillip-adams/|title=Phillip Adams AO|work=Speaker Profile|publisher=The Celebrity Speakers Bureau|date=2014|accessdate=23 December 2014}} Adams is the author or editor of more than 20 books, including ''The Unspeakable Adams'', ''Adams Versus God'', ''The Penguin Book of Australian Jokes'', ''Retreat from Tolerance'', ''Talkback and A Billion Voices'', ''Adams Ark'', and, with Lee Burton, ''Emperors of the Air''. [[Robert Manne]] has described Adams as "the emblematic figurehead of the pro-[[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] left [[intelligentsia]]".{{cite news|author=Manne, Robert|authorlink=Robert Manne |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/robert-manne/labor-must-confront-its-identity-crisis/2004/10/17/1097951554223.html|location=Melbourne|work=[[The Age]]|title=Labor must confront its identity crisis|date=18 October 2004|accessdate=23 December 2014}} Adams had a close relationship with every Labor leader from Gough Whitlam to [[Kevin Rudd]], advising on public relations, advertising and policy issues. However, on 19 July 2006, he was reported as saying of the Labor Party:
They hate me. I think Kim Beazley is a serious error. I think the party's been going downhill federally ever since Keating left ... The Labor Party's hardly worth feeding federally.
In 2010, Adams resigned from the Labor Party after Rudd was defeated as the [[Leader of the Australian Labor Party|Leader of the Labor Party]] at the [[Australian Labor Party leadership election, 2010|2010 Labor leadership spill]].{{cite news|title=Why I quit the Labor Party|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/why-i-quit-the-labor-party/story-e6frg8h6-1225886243738|author=Adams, Phillip|work=[[The Australian]]|date=|accessdate= }} In 1995 Adams argued against [[Section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975]], saying that a better response to expressions of racial hatred was "public debate, not legal censure".{{Cite book|title=The Role of the Media|last=Adams|first=Phillip|publisher=|year=1995|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} Adams' life and extracurricular activities have made him a source of interest to fans and foes of all persuasions for many years. Australia's [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation|security intelligence organisation]] kept an extensive [[ASIO File]] on Adams. The file began at about the time he turned 16 years of age.{{cite news|work=[[The Australian|The Weekend Australian Magazine]]|author=Adams, Phillip|date=16 July 2005|title=Adams file|accessdate=}} ==Personal life== [[File:(1) Stoneleigh (Darley Street)-1.jpg|right|thumb|"Stoneleigh", Adams's former home]] Adams is married to [[Patrice Newell]]. He has four daughters: three with his first wife, Rosemary Fawcett, and one with Newell. He lives on "Elmswood", a large property near [[Gundy]] in the [[Hunter Region]] in mid-northern New South Wales. He and his wife grow garlic, olives and farm organically fed cattle. He has a home in [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]], an inner suburb of Sydney. Prior to this, Adams lived for some time in "Stoneleigh", a heritage-listed house{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDetails.aspx?ID=2420152|title=House "Stoneleigh" Including Interior, Front Fence and Grounds – NSW Environment & Heritage|website=www.environment.nsw.gov.au}} in [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]]. Adams is a collector of rare antiques, including Egyptian, Roman and Greek sculptures and [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifact]]s. He has written "I'd been an atheist since I was five."{{cite web|url=http://jmm.aaa.net.au/articles/4678.htm|title=I Am Proud That|author1=Adams, Phillip|author2=Croucher, Rowland|publisher=John Mark Ministries|date=October 1998|archive-url=http://www.melbournesynagogue.org.au/news/haatid/q4_1998/q4_98_02.html|archive-date=5 January 2003|accessdate=23 December 2014}} In 1979 a portrait of Adams by artist [[Wes Walters]] won the [[Archibald Prize]]. ==Honours and awards== *Windgrove Laureate (2004) *Senior [[ANZAC Fellow]] (1981) *[[Henry Lawson]] Arts Award (1987) *[[United Nations Media Award]] (2005) *Multiple AFI Awards for various films *Honorary Doctor of the University, [[Griffith University]] *Honorary Doctor of Letters, [[Edith Cowan University]] (2003){{cite web|title=ECU Honorary Award Recipients|work=[[Edith Cowan University]]|url=https://www.ecu.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/378654/ECU_Honorary_Award_Recipients.pdf}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Honorary Doctor of Letters, [[University of Sydney]] (2005){{cite web|title=Robyn Archer and Phillip Adams honoured|date=4 May 2005|work=[[The University of Sydney]]|url=http://sydney.edu.au/news/84.html?newsstoryid=29}} *Honorary Doctor of the University, [[University of South Australia]] (2010){{cite web|title=Mr Phillip Adams AO|work=[[University of South Australia]]|url=http://w3.unisa.edu.au/student/graduations/speeches/bios/2010/adams.asp}} *Honorary Doctor of Letters, [[Macquarie University]] (2014){{cite web|title=Phillip Adams AO receives honorary doctorate from Macquarie University|date=17 April 2014|publisher=[[Macquarie University]]|url=http://mq.edu.au/newsroom/2014/04/17/phillip-adams-ao-receives-honorary-doctorate-from-macquarie-university/}} *[[Officer of the Order of Australia]] (AO) 1992, for service to the Australian film and television industries{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=883101&search_type=quick&showInd=true|work=It's an Honour|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Australia]]|date=26 January 1992|title=Adams, Phillip Andrew: Officer of the Order of Australia|accessdate=}} *[[Member of the Order of Australia]] (AM) 1987, for service to the arts, particularly to film and television{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=883146&search_type=quick&showInd=true|work=It's an Honour|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Australia]]|date=26 January 1987|title=Adams, Phillip Andrew Hedley: Member of the Order of Australia|accessdate=}} *[[Australian Living Treasures|Living Treasures]] by the [[National Trust of Australia|National Trust]] in 1998 *[[Walkley Award]] for Broadcast Journalism (2004) *Responsibility in Journalism Award 1998 (SCICOP) New York *Australian Republican of the Year 2005 (Australian Republican Party) *[[Australian Humanist of the Year]] 1987 – Awarded by the [[Council of Australian Humanist Societies]] *Australian Centenary Medal (1 January 2001) [http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1126132&search_type=quick&showInd=true] "''For service to Australian society in journalism''" *[[Raymond Longford Award]] (the Australian film industry's highest accolade, in 1981, for "Outstanding Services to the Australian Film Industry" *A minor planet, discovered by R.H. McNaught at Siding Spring (1990) was named "Phillipadams" by the [[International Astronomical Union]] (1997) * [[Human Rights Medal]] awarded by the Australian Government's [[Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission]] (2006) (Shared with [[Father Chris Riley]]) *In 1996 the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] (CSICOP) presented Adams with the ''Responsibility in Journalism'' Award.{{cite journal|title=CSICOP Award Winners|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=1996|volume=20|issue=5|page=7}} ==Bibliography== {{div col|colwidth=25em}} *''Conversations'' *''A Billion Voices'' *''Classic Columns'' *''Adams Ark'' (2004) *''Adams Versus God'' *''Retreat from Tolerance'' *''The Uncensored Adams'' *''The Inflammable Adams'' *''The Unspeakable Adams'' *''More Unspeakable Adams'' *''Adams with Added Enzymes'' *''Talkback: Emperors of the Air'' *''Adams Vs. God: The Rematch'' (2007) *''Harrold Cazneaux: The Quiet Observer'' *''The Big Questions'' (with Professor Paul Davies) *''More Big Questions'' (with Professor Paul Davies) *''Bedtime Stories – Tales from my 21 Years at Late Night Live'' : *With his partner [[Patrice Newell]], he is the author of several joke books: **''The Penguin Book of Australian Jokes'' (1994) **''The Penguin Book of Jokes from Cyberspace'' (1995) **''The Penguin Book of More Australian Jokes'' (1996) **''The Penguin Book of Schoolyard Jokes'' (1997) {{div col end}} ==Filmography== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} === Film === * ''A Personal History of the Australian Surf'' * ''Hearts and Minds'' (1966) (producer) * ''[[Jack and Jill: A Postscript]]'' (1970) (producer, writer, director) * ''[[The Naked Bunyip]]'' (1970) (producer) * ''[[The Adventures of Barry McKenzie]]'' (1972) (producer) * ''[[Don's Party]]'' (1976) (producer) * ''[[The Getting of Wisdom (film)|The Getting of Wisdom]]'' (1978) (producer) * ''[[Grendel Grendel Grendel]]'' (1981) (producer) * ''[[Fighting Back (1982 American film)|Fighting Back]]'' (1982) (executive producer) * ''[[Lonely Hearts (1982 film)|Lonely Hearts]]'' (1982) (executive producer) * ''[[We of the Never Never]]'' (1982) (executive producer) * ''[[Kitty and the Bagman]]'' (1983) (producer) * ''[[Abra Cadabra]]'' (1983) (producer) * ''[[Dallas Doll]]'' (1994) as Radio Announcer * ''[[Road to Nhill]]'' (1997) as God (voice) === Television === * ''Adams' Australia'' (part of BBC TV's contribution to Australia's celebrations for its [[Australian Bicentenary|bicentenary]]). * ''The Big Questions'' with Professor [[Paul Davies]] * ''Death and Destiny'' filmed in Egypt with Paul Cox. * ''More Big Questions'' with Professor Paul Davies * ''Face The Press'' SBS * ''Short Cuts'' ABC * ''[[Four Corners (Australian TV program)|Four Corners]]'' * ''[[This Day Tonight]]'' * ''[[Parkinson (TV series)|Parkinson]]'' * ''[[7:30 Report]]'' * ''[[Clive James]]'' * ''Will Be Back After This Break'' (7 Network) * ''Two Shot'' series 1 and 2 (ABC) * ''Short and Sweet'' (2 6-part series, ABC) * ''[[Talking Heads (Australian TV series)|Talking Heads]]'' * ''[[Compass (TV program)|Compass]]'' * ''[[Sunday (Australian TV program)|Sunday]]'' * ''[[A Current Affair (Australian TV series)|A Current Affair]]'' * ''[[60 Minutes (Australian TV program)|Sixty Minutes]]'' * ''[[Australian Story]]'' * ''Counterpoint with William F. Buckley Jr'' * ''[[CNNNN]]'' * ''[[The Chaser's War on Everything]]'' * Compere, Australian Film Institute Awards Telecast * Co-presenter, the Australian Bicentennial Celebration {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/latenightlive/podcasts/ ABC ''Late Night Live'' podcasts] * [http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/phillip-adams/2913410 Biography (ABC)] * [http://www.ourcommunity.com.au/files/Adams.pdf Why We Need a Revolution Now] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094014/http://quadrant.org.au/php/article_view.php?article_id=1163 My Life as Phillip Adams: A Memoir (Imre Salusinszky)] *{{IMDb name|0011270}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Raymond Longford Award}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, Phillip}} [[Category:Australian film producers]] [[Category:Australian humanists]] [[Category:Australian atheists]] [[Category:People from Maryborough, Victoria]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Recipients of the Centenary Medal]] [[Category:Victorian College of the Arts alumni]] [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Australian Living Treasures]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Walkley Award winners]] [[Category:ABC journalists associated with the Australian Labor Party]] [[Category:ABC radio (Australia) journalists and presenters]] [[Category:Australian Book Review people]]

revision.comment: /* Forensic rehabilitation counselors */ I took out some information that had obviously been copied and pasted from a university advertisement. I also removed some opinionated statements.
revision.text:
'''Rehabilitation counseling''' is focused on helping people who have [[disabilities]] achieve their personal, career, and independent living goals through a [[counseling]] process.
Rehabilitation Counselors can be found in private practice, in [[Physical therapy|rehabilitation]] facilities, hospitals, universities, schools, government agencies, insurance companies and other organizations where people are being treated for [[Congenital disorder|congenital]] or acquired disabilities. Over time, with the changes in [[social work]] being more psychotherapy-oriented, rehabilitation counselors take on more and more [[community engagement]] work, especially as it relates to special populations. Some rehabilitation counselors focus solely on community engagement through vocational services, others in various states qualify as both a certified rehabilitation counselor (CRC) and a [[licensed professional counselor]] (LPC), enabling them to focus on [[psychotherapy]].
==History==
=== United States === Historically, rehabilitation counselors primarily served working-age adults with disabilities. Today, the need for rehabilitation counseling services extends to persons of all age groups who have disabilities. Rehabilitation counselors also may provide general and specialized counseling to people with disabilities in public human service programs and private practice settings.<ref name="ama-assn.org">[http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/category/16070.html AMA (Med Ed Products) Rehabilitation counselor<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Initially, rehabilitation professionals were recruited from a variety of human service disciplines, including public health nursing, social work, and school counseling. Although educational programs began to appear in the 1940s, it was not until the availability of federal funding for rehabilitation counseling programs in 1954 that the profession began to grow and establish its own identity.
==== Education and training ==== Though no specific undergraduate degree is required, the majority of rehabilitation counseling graduate students have undergraduate degrees in rehabilitation services, psychology, sociology, or other human services-related fields. As a master's degree is required at a minimum, rehabilitation counselors are trained at the graduate level, with most earning a master's degree, and a few continuing on to the Doctoral level.<ref>[http://www.chhs.niu.edu/rehab_services/graduate/roles_responsibilities.shtml Northern Illinois University Graduate Program]</ref> The Council on Rehabilitation Education (CORE)<ref>[http://www.core-rehab.org/ Council on Rehabilitation Education (CORE)]</ref> accredits qualifying institutions, though not all programs meet accreditation requirements, prohibiting some graduates from professional certification/licensure. Rehabilitation counselors are trained in the following areas: * Individual and group counseling * Medical and psychosocial information * Problems and [[community engagement]] of special populations * Evaluation and assessment * Research utilization * Employment and occupational choice * Case and caseload management * Job development and placement
Accredited rehabilitation counselor education programs typically provide 60 credit hours of academic and field-based clinical training. Clinical training consists of at least a semester of practicum and a minimum of 600 hours of supervised internship experience. Clinical field experiences are available in a variety of community, state, federal, and private rehabilitation-related programs.
==== Professional certification and licensure ==== The [[Commission on Rehabilitation Counselor Certification (CRCC)]] grants certification to counselors who meet educational requirements and have passed an examination indicating that they possess the competency and skill to become a Certified Rehabilitation Counselor, (CRC in the United States; CCRC in Canada). A Master's degree is required to obtain certification. Certification as a rehabilitation counselor is not mandated by any state or federal laws, however eligibility to sit for the certification exam is mandated by federal law for those wishing to work for state/federal vocational rehabilitation systems. Some states have Licensed Rehabilitation Counselors (LRC), which places LRCs at the same level as other licensed social service professionals. In other states the CRC qualifies the rehabilitation counselor to obtain the Licensure as a Professional Counselor (LPC). Certification is highly desirable to many employers.
==== Social relevancy ==== Community service to a culturally and ethnically diverse population, professional functions, critical thinking, [[advocacy]], applied research activities, and ethical standards are integrated throughout rehabilitation counselor preparation and development.<ref>[http://rehab.siu.edu/degree/rc_intro.html SIUC Rehabilitation Counseling Dept.]</ref> Though rehabilitation counselors are adept at understanding medical issues surrounding the disability (as proven by certification/licensure), they are trained in the [[social model of disability]], which identifies systemic barriers, negative attitudes and exclusion by society (purposely or inadvertently) that mean society is the main contributory factor in disabling people. Rehabilitation Counselors are often advocates in the community for people with disabilities outside of the workplace, with most doing some form of [[community engagement]]. As a good portion of counselors have disabilities themselves, the counseling process often emphasizes self-advocacy skills. Rehabilitation counselors can be found in the leadership of many prominent organizations that support [[human rights]] and civil rights for people with disabilities such as [[American Coalition of Citizens with Disabilities]], [[National Black Deaf Advocates]], etc.<ref>[http://www3.law.columbia.edu/hrlr/hrlr_journal/42.2/Kanter.pdf Syracuse University Disability Law and Policy]</ref>
===== Notable rehabilitation counselors ===== * [[Antonia Darder|Antonia Darder Aguilo]] - Public Intellectual, Leavey Presidential Endowed Chair in Ethics and Moral Leadership in the School of Education at Loyola Marymount University * [[Bill G. Chapman]] - Air Force Veteran, Blind/Vision-impaired advocate * [[Bill Copeland (poet)|Bill Copeland]] - Award-winning Poet * [[Laurence Foley|Laurence M. Foley]] - American Diplomat to Jordan * [[Patricia Gerard]] - First female Mayor of Largo, FL * [[Juan de Dios Ramírez Heredia]] - Spanish Romani politician * [[Al Jarreau]] - Grammy-winning Jazz Musician * [[Young Woo Kang]] - First Korean man with vision impairment to earn a PhD, Creator of braille alphabet for the Korean language * [[Robert Kelly (navy)|Robert Kelly]] - Navy Veteran, Film-inspiration * [[Kathleen Kenna]] - Canadian Journalist in Afghanistan * [[Erin Pac]] - U.S. Olympic Bobsledder, 2010 Bronze-medal winner * [[Dianne Primavera]] - U.S. Legislator for the state of Colorado * [[Kathleen Hawk Sawyer]] - Former Director of U.S. Federal Bureau of Prisons * [[Alberta Banner Turner]] - First African-American woman to earn a PhD in Psychology from The Ohio State University * [[National Black Deaf Advocates|Ronnie Mae Tyson]] - First Miss Black Deaf America
==Rehabilitation counseling careers==
=== Careers in the profession === In the United States, many rehabilitation counselors work in a variety of arenas. The predominant placement of rehabilitation counselors are state rehabilitation programs as Vocational Counselors, social service agencies as Administrators, and at the collegiate level as Disability Counselors/Specialists:
==== State rehabilitation programs ==== The predominant need for rehabilitation counselors is within federal/state funded vocational rehabilitation programs. While the Veterans Benefits Administration has its own vocational rehabilitation program, the rest of Federal/State Vocational Rehabilitation Programs are funded and regulated by the Rehabilitation Services Administration (RSA), a division of the U.S Department of Education. Although policies vary from state to state, rehabilitation counselors who work in the federal/state systems typically must hold a master's degree in rehabilitation counseling, special education or a related field, and are required to be certified or be eligible to sit for the certification examination. People accepting employment in the federal/state Vocational Rehabilitation programs do so with the agreement they will meet these qualifications by a specified date to maintain employment.
==== Social service agencies and the corporate sector ==== Rehabilitation Counselors can work in the non-profit/corporate sector in various ways. Though the majority start as counselors, specializing in career counseling, most rehabilitation counselors that work in the non-profit arena rise to the administration level, either in supervising staff or directing programs for people with disabilities.<ref>[http://www.crccertification.com/filebin/pdf/careercenter/CRCresources_CRCScope.pdf Scope of Practice]</ref> Others supervise staff that work in case management programs that serve people with disabilities. Some rehabilitation counselors work with [[Centers for Independent Living|Independent Living Centers]], doing [[community engagement]], advocacy, outside referrals, and social service provision for people with disabilities.<ref>[http://www.nysilc.org/council.htm NY State Independent Living Council]</ref> Entrepreneurial rehabilitation counselors also work as consultants, establishing their own private service agencies. Counselors in working with corporations focus on community relations or corporate service, serving as liaisons between companies and charities or service programs.
==== College disability counselors and specialists ==== By law all [[community college]]s, colleges and universities are required to make reasonable accommodations for students with disabilities. To satisfy this requirement most collegial settings have a Disability Resources Center, a Special Needs Coordinator or a similar office. Staff are responsible for coordinating services that ''may'' include but are not limited to: advocacy/liaison, computer access, counseling (academic, personal, vocational), equipment loan, information/referral services, in-service awareness programs, notetakers, on campus orientation and mobility training for visually impaired students, priority registration assistance, readers, scribes, shuttle (on-campus), sign language interpreters, test proctoring/testing accommodations, and tutors.
Some adaptive technological accommodations ''may'' include but are not limited to: Adaptive computer technology (including voice activated and speech output), Assistive listening devices, Films/videotapes about disabilities, Kurzweil personal reader, Large print software,Print enlargers (CCTV), Raised-line drawing kit, Tactile map of campus, Talking calculators, Tape recorders/APH Talking Book Machine, TDD for hearing impaired, Wheelchair, Wheelchair access maps.<ref>[http://www.foothill.edu/al/drc.php Adaptive Learning Division - Disability Resource Center<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Students who have documentation proving their disability status and the staff are trained to access or have knowledge of the necessary services according to the students' unique need. As the college level is different from the primary school system, the same services that a student may have received within a special education program in high school may not be required at the collegiate level. A wide variety of students with disabilities can be served, some examples are individuals with: learning disabilities, sensorial disabilities (hearing loss, vision loss, etc.), physical disabilities (cerebral palsy, etc.) and psychological disabilities.
==== Forensic rehabilitation counselors ==== Forensic rehabilitation counselors can work as consultants, serving as witnesses and advocates in the legal profession. Forensic rehab counselors serve as legal advisors with specialized information on disability in the areas of higher education access, Social Security, marital dissolution, personal injury, and Worker’s Compensation.
According to a survey of 1,220 Certified Rehabilitation Counselors(CRC) conducted by the Commission on Rehabilitation Counselor Certification (CORE), CRCs working within a forensic/expert witness job function have the highest annual salary ($93,000) of all job functions analyzed. Furthermore, when average salaries were analyzed by primary work setting, CRCs working within business or industry have the highest annual salary ($78,000) of all settings listed, which is $30,000 more than CRCs working in state/federal rehabilitation agencies. High annual salaries in the forensic area may be a key attraction for CRCs seeking to transition from the public sector.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Forensic Vocational Rehabilitation Program|url=http://bsch.phhp.ufl.edu/distance-learning/forensic-vocational-rehabilitation/forensic-vocational-rehabilitation-program/|website=University of Florida Forensic Vocational Rehabilitation Program}}</ref> Academic programs require a graduate degree from an accredited rehabilitation counseling program, and enable the student to: learn about the role that counselors provide within the legal system; gain expertise in the ethical standards expected of expert witnesses; learn about the processes followed within legal cases when testifying on one’s expert opinion; gain an understanding of the business aspects of a forensic counselor’s work that breed success in this area of specialization.
== Growth of the field ==
=== Job outlook === As of 2010 there were 129,800 working in the field. Jobs for rehabilitation counselors are expected to grow by 28 percent, which is much faster than the average for all occupations.<ref>[http://www.bls.gov/ooh/community-and-social-service/rehabilitation-counselors.htm BLS Occupational Outlook Handbook]</ref>
=== Professional development === There are several professional organizations Rehabilitation Counselors and other rehabilitation professionals belong to, including the American Rehabilitation Counseling Association, National Rehabilitation Counseling Association, and American Rehabilitation Action Network. Though there is no nationwide union or lobbying organization supporting rehabilitation counselors (such as is the case with social workers, or psychologists), the [[Commission on Rehabilitation Counselor Certification (CRCC)]] does a lot of work in organizing rehabilitation counselors that pursue the professional advancement of the young field.
==See also== * [[Career development]] * [[Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities]] * [[European Platform for Rehabilitation]] * [[Public service]] * [[Social change]] * [[Social development]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== {{external links|date=March 2015}} * [http://www.ed.gov/about/offices/list/osers/rsa/index.html Rehabilitation Services Administration] * [http://www.crccertification.com/ Commission on Rehabilitation Counselor Certification] * [http://www.arcaweb.org/ American Rehabilitation Counseling Association] * [http://www.nationalrehab.org/website/index.html National Rehabilitation Association] * [http://nrca-net.org/ National Rehabilitation Counseling Association] * [http://www.chhs.niu.edu/rehab_services/graduate/index.shtml NIU Rehabilitation Counseling - Deafness/Deaf-Blind Specialization] * [http://portal.texastechrehabcounseling.com Rehabilitation Counseling Program Student Portal, TTUHSC] * [http://education.msu.edu/cepse/rehab/default.asp Michigan State University Rehabilitation Counseling Program] * [http://gse.buffalo.edu/online/rehab Rehabilitation Counseling program, UB Graduate School of Education] * [http://www.ttuhsc.edu/sah/mrc/ Master of Rehabilitation Counseling program, TTUHSC School of Allied Health] * [http://www.rehabilitationcounselors.org/ The Rehabilitation Counseling Network]
[[Category:Counseling]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''''Residual value''''' is one of the constituents of a [[leasing]] calculus or operation. It describes the future value of a good in terms of absolute value in monetary terms and it is sometimes abbreviated into a percentage of the initial price when the item was new.
Example: A car is sold at a list price of $20,000 today. After a usage of 36 months and 50,000 miles its value is contractually defined as $10,000 or 50%. The credited amount, on which the interest is applied, thus is $20,000 present value minus $10,000 future value.
Residual values are contractually dealt with either in terms of [[closed contract]]s or [[open contract]]s.
In accounting, residual value is another name for [[salvage value]], the remaining value of an asset after it has been fully depreciated.
The residual value derives its calculation from a base price, calculated after [[depreciation]].
Residual values are calculated using a number of factors, generally a vehicles market value for the term and mileage required is the start point for the calculation, followed by seasonality, monthly adjustment, lifecycle and disposal performance. The leasing company setting the residual values (RVs) will use their own historical information to insert the adjustment factors within the calculation to set the end value being the residual value.
In accounting, the residual value could be defined as an estimated amount that an entity can obtain when disposing of an asset after its useful life has ended. When doing this the estimated costs of disposing of the asset should be deducted.
The formula to calculate the residual value can be seen with the next example as follows:
A company owns a machine which was bought for €20,000. This machine has a useful life of five years which has just ended. The company knows that if it sells the machine now it will be able to recover 10% of the price of acquisition.
Therefore, the residual value would be:
<math>\text{Residual value} = 10\% \times (20{,}000) = 2{,}000</math>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Residual Value}} [[Category:Business economics]] [[Category:Leasing]]
{{Econ-stub}}

{{Infobox politician |name = Somkid Jatusripitak
สมคิด จาตุศรีพิทักษ์ |honorific-prefix = |honorific-suffix = |nationality = [[Thailand|Thai]] |image = SomkidJat2006.JPG | image_size = 200px |office = [[Prime Minister of Thailand#Deputy Prime Minister|Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand]] |term_start = 20 August 2015 |term_end = |primeminister = [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] |predecessor = |successor = |term_start3 = 9 October 2001 |term_end3 = 3 October 2002 |primeminister3= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |term_start2 = 8 February 2003 |term_end2 = 10 March 2004 |primeminister2= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |term_start1 = 11 March 2005 |term_end1 = 19 September 2006 |primeminister1= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |office4 = [[Ministry of Finance (Thailand)|Minister of Finance]] |term_start4 = 10 March 2004 |term_end4 = 2 August 2005 |primeminister4= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |predecessor4 = [[Suchart Chaovisith]] |successor4= [[Thanong Bidaya]] |term_start5 = 17 February 2001 |term_end5 = 8 January 2003 |primeminister5= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |predecessor5 =[[Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda]] |successor5 = [[Suchart Chaovisith]] |office6 = [[Ministry of Commerce (Thailand)|Minister of Commerce]] |term_start6 = 3 August 2005 |term_end6 = 19 September 2006 |primeminister6= [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] |predecessor6 =[[Thanong Bidaya]] |successor6 = [[Krirk-Krai Jirapaet]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|7|15|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Thai Rak Thai Party|Thai Rak Thai]] (1998-2007) |spouse = Aruratchani Jatusripitak |profession = [[Economist]]
[[Politician]] |religion = [[Buddhism]] |alma_mater = [[Thammasat University]]
[[National Institute of Development Administration]]
[[Northwestern University]] |signature = Signature of Somkid Jatusripitak.svg |}} '''Somkid Jatusripitak''' ({{lang-th|สมคิด จาตุศรีพิทักษ์}}, {{RTGS|Somkhit Chatusiphithak}}, {{zh|曾汉光}};[http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2005-07-04/09066342488s.shtml 他信赴潮寻根颂奇回汕祭祖] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529173119/http://news.sina.com.cn/c/2005-07-04/09066342488s.shtml |date=May 29, 2014 }} born 15 July 1953) is a Thai economist, business theorist, and politician. A mentee of [[Philip Kotler]], he has (co-)authored books on competitiveness and taught marketing at Thai universities. He was a co-founder and leader of the [[Thai Rak Thai Party]] (TRT) and was mainly responsible for developing the party's progressive and reformist economic and social platform. After the party's electoral victory, he served as Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Finance, and Minister of Commerce in [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s government. Following the [[2006 Thai coup d'état|coup d'état in 2006]], the junta chose him as an economic envoy, advocating the royally-endorsed "[[self-sufficiency]]" economic agenda. After another [[2014 Thai coup d'état|military coup in 2014]], he served as the junta's advisor on foreign economic relations. Since September 2014 he has been a full member of the so-called [[National Council for Peace and Order]]. ==Early life== Somkid was born in Bangkok and grew up in a large, but modest [[Thai Chinese]] ([[Teochew people|Teochew]]) family, one of 10 children.[http://members.tripod.com/thanong/02152001.htm Somkid promises he'll do it his way]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}[http://216.109.125.130/search/cache?p=Somkid+Jatusripitak+chinese&ei=UTF-8&fp_ip=SG&meta=0&fl=0&fr=yfp-t-501&u=yaleglobal.yale.edu/display.article%3Fid%3D2875&w=somkid+jatusripitak+chinese&d=bqXAKPmdOiG3&icp=1&.intl=us YaleGlobal]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} His great-great grandfather immigrated from [[China]] during the reign of the [[Jiaqing Emperor]][http://news.sina.com.cn/s/2005-07-03/12106336925s.shtml 泰国副总理颂奇回汕省亲祭祖 林木声黄志光等前往机场迎接] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303184053/http://news.sina.com.cn/s/2005-07-03/12106336925s.shtml |date=March 3, 2016 }} (early 19th century). Despite being born and raised in Thailand, Somkid still speaks Thai with a strong Chinese accent.{{Cite book |author1=Pasuk Phongpaichit |authorlink1=Pasuk Phongpaichit |author2=Chris Baker |authorlink2=Chris Baker (writer) |title=Thaksin: The Business of Politics in Thailand |publisher=NIAS Press |place=Copenhagen |year=2004|pages=169–170}}{{Cite news |author="[[Chang Noi]]" |title=The culture of PM Thaksin |newspaper=The Nation |date=3 March 2003}} One of his older brothers, [[Som Jatusripitak]] later became president of Siam City Bank and Commerce Minister in [[Chavalit Yongchaiyudh]]'s government.[http://thanong.tripod.com/05182000.htm 05182000] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212320/http://thanong.tripod.com/05182000.htm |date=March 3, 2016 }} His wife, Anurachanee Jatusripitak, teaches at [[Chulalongkorn University]]. They have three children.{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} ==Education and academic career== Somkid went to Triam Udom Suksa School and graduated with a bachelor's degree from the Faculty of Economics, [[Thammasat University]] in 1972. Later, he completed an MBA in Finance from the Graduate School of Business Administration (NIDA Business School), [[National Institute of Development Administration]] (NIDA) and a Ph.D. in marketing from the [[Kellogg School of Management]] at [[Northwestern University]]. After graduating, he joined a teaching position and became Associate Professor in Marketing at the Graduate School of Business Administration (NIDA Business School). He also served as an Associate Dean at NIDA Business School. Somkid's thinking was greatly influenced by [[Michael Porter]]'s "Competitiveness of Nations". He focused much of his academic research on the development of national and business competitiveness. Along with his mentor [[Philip Kotler]], he was a strong supporter of the concept of [[Nation Branding]]. In 1997, Somkid co-authored "The Marketing of Nations: A Strategic Approach to Building National Wealth" with [[Philip Kotler]]. The book outlined how countries could improve their competitiveness through marketing and appropriate policies to support it. Somkid's book, ''Borisat Prathet Thai'' ("Thailand Inc: Concepts and Strategy"), stressed how Thailand should use marketing to improve its competitiveness. ==Business career== Somkid was a co-founder of the Manager Media Group, along with [[Sondhi Limthongkul]].[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/search/page.arcview.php?clid=6&id=58371 Bangkok's Independent Newspaper] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312004752/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/search/page.arcview.php?clid=6&id=58371 |date=March 12, 2007 }} He played a role in the establishment of the Phatra Research Institute. He became a Director of the Saha Pattanapibul Group, a major Thai consumer goods conglomerate. He was appointed to become Advisor of the [[Stock Exchange of Thailand]], Director of PTTEP, and Director of the [[PTT Public Company Limited|Petroleum Authority of Thailand]]. ==Political career== ===Advisor to Foreign Minister Thaksin Shinawatra=== Somkid became secretary to Foreign Minister Thaksin Shinawatra under [[Banharn Silpa-Archa]]'s government (1995–96). ===Advisor to Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya=== Somkid became secretary to Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya under [[Chavalit Yongchaiyudh]]'s government (1996–97). ===Founding of the Thai Rak Thai Party=== Somkid was one of the co-founders of the Thai Rak Thai party in 1998, along with party leader Thaksin Shinawatra. His senior stature in the party was apparent from his no. 3 position in the TRT's 2001 election party list, behind Thaksin Shinawatra and Purachai Piemsomboon. Somkid has been called "the man behind ''Thaksinomics''",[http://www.epw.org.in/showArticles.php?root=2005&leaf=07&filename=8901&filetype=html]{{dead link|date=May 2014}} and was the mastermind of the populist policies that helped propel the Thai Rak Thai party to a landslide election victory in 2001. The TRT "won by embracing populism on a grand scale," said the Far Eastern Economic Review. Somkid's chief policy innovations included the universal healthcare program, 1 million THB development funds for each of Thailand's 70,000 villages, a 3-year loan freeze for farmers, fast-track privatization of state enterprises, and a national asset management corporation (AMC) to buy up the $20 billion in bad debt carried by Thai banks.[http://www.pathfinder.com/asiaweek/magazine/nations/0,8782,100225,00.html Asiaweek.com | On The Hot Seat | 2/3/2001] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221125834/http://www.pathfinder.com/asiaweek/magazine/nations/0,8782,100225,00.html |date=December 21, 2007 }}{{Cite book |author1=[[Duncan McCargo]] |author2=Ukrist Pathmanand |title=The Thaksinization of Thailand |place=Copenhagen |publisher=NIAS Press |year=2005 |pages=97–98}} Somkid also pioneered the TRT party's rural small and medium enterprise (SME) policy. Noting that agriculture remains the most important economic sector, employing 60-70% of the Thai population, the economic challenge was to develop the agricultural sector and link it with the modern sector. This became one of the founding principles of the Thaksin government's popular [[One Tambon One Product]] (OTOP) program. At the time, ''The Nation'' newspaper exclaimed that these policies "amount to a revolution in Thai public policy".[http://thanong.tripod.com/01112001.htm Somkid - who else could it be?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061420/http://thanong.tripod.com/01112001.htm |date=March 4, 2016 }} ===Minister in Thaksin's government=== From the TRT's landslide election win of 2001, Somkid was a core member of Thakin's economic inner cabinet - starting off as Finance Minister and then becoming Commerce Minister. ====Finance Minister==== {{prose|section|date=May 2014}} In his term as Finance Minister (February 2001 to February 2003), Somkid *oversaw a management reshuffle at state-owned [[Thai Airways International]] *led the establishment of the national asset management corporation (AMC) *supported the controversial restructuring of [[Prachai Leophai-ratana]]'s [[TPI_Polene|Thai Petrochemical Industry]] (TPI)Bangkok Post, [http://sanpaworn.vissaventure.com/log/149/tpi-update Chinese conglomerate said to seek majority stake in TPI] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529165038/http://sanpaworn.vissaventure.com/log/149/tpi-update |date=May 29, 2014 }}, 27 May 2005 *In 2002, Somkid established the ''village fund program''. This program gave each of Thailand's 70,000 villages a self-managed fund of 1 million THB (approx. 25,000 USD), to be used for grassroots social and economic investments. ====Commerce Minister==== {{prose|section|date=May 2014}} In his term as Commerce Minister (August 2005 to September 2006), Somkid * oversaw the recovery of tourism industry in the Andaman coast after the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|tsunami of 2004]] * agreed to draw up a comprehensive road map for increasing trade, investment and cooperation with the United Kingdom[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/06/09/pda/business_30006098.html Bangkok's Independent Newspaper] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303203830/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/06/09/pda/business_30006098.html |date=March 3, 2016 }} * boosted Board of Investment incentives in three target sectors - electronics, petrochemicals and vehicle tyres[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/05/23/business/business_30004653.php BoI okays additional incentives for investors] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303170953/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/05/23/business/business_30004653.php |date=March 3, 2016 }} During the [[2005–06 Thai political crisis|anti-Thaksin demonstrations of 2005-2006]], Thaksin noted that Somkid was one of four individuals who might succeed him as Prime Minister if he stepped down. In March 2006, during the height of the anti-Thaksin protests, Somkid underwent [[balloon angioplasty]] surgery to relieve a blood clot in an artery near his heart.[http://www.manager.co.th/IHT/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9490000039755 IHT ThaiDay - Manager Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165315/http://www.manager.co.th/IHT/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9490000039755 |date=March 3, 2016 }} After [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s announcement that he would not accept the Premiership from Parliament after the April 2006 elections, Somkid was widely seen as a potential replacement. In a poll of businessmen, 57% said Somkid was the most suitable candidate for new premier. The next highest TRT politician was Bhokin Bhalakula, who received only 12%.[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/07/politics/politics_30001181.php Businessmen put Somkid in box seat] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202734/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/07/politics/politics_30001181.php |date=March 3, 2016 }} Soon later, a broad coalition of TRT factions, including Wang Nam Yom (130 MPs), Rim Nam (15 MPs), Lamtakong (7 MPs), Wang Phya Nag (10 MPs), Chon Buri (7 MPs) and the Central provinces (10 MPs) decided to push for Somkid Jatusripitak as the next prime minister.[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/07/headlines/headlines_30001187.php Somkid takes an early lead in race to become prime minister] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214239/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/07/headlines/headlines_30001187.php |date=March 3, 2016 }} ===Aftermath of the 2006 coup=== The Thai military staged a successful [[2006 Thailand coup|coup]] against the Thaksin government on 19 September 2006. At the time, Somkid was in [[Paris]], attending the Thai-France Cultural Exhibition with Princess [[Sirindhorn]] and Foreign Minister [[Kantathi Supamongkhon]]. On 21 September 2006 arrived back to Bangkok.The Nation. {{cite web |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid%3D30014251 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224235209/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30014251 |archivedate=2007-12-24 |df= }}, Somkid arrives at Don Muang Unlike several other senior members of Thaksin's Cabinet, he was not arrested by the [[CDRM|junta]]. Somkid kept a low profile, until on 2 October 2006 he resigned from the Thai Rak Thai Party, along with Thaksin Shinawatra.The Nation, Oct. 2, 2006 [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/10/03/headlines/headlines_30015263.php Thaksin resigns from Thai Rak Thai] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183911/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/10/03/headlines/headlines_30015263.php |date=March 3, 2016 }}The Nation, Oct. 2, 2006 [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30015265 Somkid resigns from Thai Rak Thai Party] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012000000/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30015265 |date=October 12, 2006 }} He continued to lead a low profile, until in February 2007, he was appointed head of a government committee charged with "preaching" King [[Bhumibol]]'s [[self-sufficient economy]] policy. The appointment provoked great controversy, as critics claimed that the populist economics czar had no role promoting self-sufficiency.The Nation, [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/18/national/national_30027159.php More flak over role for Somkid] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303195305/http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/18/national/national_30027159.php |date=March 3, 2016 }}, 18 February 2007The Nation, [http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30027069 Banharn criticises Surayud for appointing Somkid as economic envoy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207095348/http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30027069 |date=December 7, 2008 }}, 18 February 2007 Somkid appointment was supported by General [[Saprang Kalyanamitr]], a powerful member of the junta, and [[Sondhi Limthongkul]] of the [[People's Alliance for Democracy]], a long-time colleague of Somkid's. Somkid later decided to resign from the committee, which was then dissolved. Somkid's long-time rival, Finance Minister [[Pridiyathorn Devakula]] volunteered to help perform the committee's role, and denied any role in Somkid's resignation.Bangkok Post, [http://pages.citebite.com/o1b1p3x7t7sax Pridiyathorn: No need to replace Somkid] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230845/http://pages.citebite.com/o1b1p3x7t7sax |date=March 3, 2016 }}, 21 February 2007 In early May 2007, a group of former elected senators said they were ready to support Somkid in forming a new political party, the so-called Dharma Thippatai group. Among those included Suraporn Danaitangtrakoon, Anek Laothamatas (former leader of the [[Mahachon Party]]), and former Thai Rak Thai members [[Suranand Vejjajiva]] and [[Pimol Srivikorn]].The Nation, [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/05/10/politics/politics_30033826.php Former senators-elect back Somkid] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314112113/http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/05/10/politics/politics_30033826.php |date=March 14, 2012 }}, 10 May 2007 On 26 June 2007, they founded [[Ruam Jai Thai]]. However, on 30 May 2007 the Constitutional Tribunal had produced a [[2006 Thai political party dissolution charges|verdict]], barring all 111 former executive members of Thai Rak Thai Party, including Somkid, from holding political office for five years.{{Cite news |author=Jon Fernquest |title=Institute, not politics, now Somkid's focus |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/learning/learning-from-news/305036/somkid-jatusripitak-research-institute-not-politics |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=30 July 2012}} In 2012, Somkid founded the ''Thailand Future Study Institute'', a [[think tank]] which is sponsored by major Thai business corporations and seeks to provide research and consulting to public bodies and private sector. ===Advisor and member of the 2014 junta === [[File:President Rodrigo Roa Duterte is joined by Thailand Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak as he walks past the honor guards (02).jpg|thumb| Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak with President [[Rodrigo Roa Duterte]] at the Royal Thai Air Force, Military Air Terminal in Bangkok]] After the [[2014 Thai coup d'état|22 May 2014 coup d'état]], the junta—which calls itself [[National Council for Peace and Order]] (NCPO)—appointed Somkid member of its "advisory board" in charge of foreign economic relations, especially with Asian countries China and Japan.{{Cite news |title=Prawit, Somkid, Pridiyathorn named advisers |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=27 May 2014 |url=http://bangkokpost.com/news/local/412074/prawit-somkid-pridiyathorn-named-advisers}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/412579/ncpo-lays-out-stages-to-next-poll |title=NCPO lays out stages to next poll |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=29 May 2014}} On 16 September Somkid—as one of two civilians— was appointed as a member of the NCPO.{{Cite news |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/432553/somkid-meechai-sit-on-ncpo |title=Somkid, Meechai sit on NCPO |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=16 September 2014}} == Selected works == * (co-authored with Philip Kotler and Liam Fahey). {{Cite book |title=The New Competition |place=Englewood Cliffs, N.J. |publisher=Prentice-Hall |year=1985 |isbn=0136120784}} * {{Cite book |title=The Exporting Behavior of Manufacturing Firms |place=Ann Arbor, Mich. |publisher=UMI Research Press |year=1986 |isbn=0835717232}} * (co-authored with Philip Kotler and Suvit Maesincee). {{Cite book |title=The Marketing of Nations: A strategic approach to building national wealth |publisher=Free Press |place=New York |year=1997 |isbn=068483488X}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} Chaovisith]]}} {{s-ttl|title= [[Ministry of Finance (Thailand)|Minister of Finance]]|years=2004-2005}} {{s-aft|after=[[Thanong Bidaya]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Somkid {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox airport | name = Sywell Aerodrome | nativename = Northampton/Sywell Aerodrome | IATA = ORM | ICAO = EGBK | image= Sywell Aerodrome.jpg | type = Private | owner-oper = Sywell Aerodrome Ltd. | location = [[Northampton]] | city-served = [[Northampton]], [[Wellingborough]], [[Kettering]] and [[Rushden]] | elevation-f = 424 | coordinates = {{coord|52|18|22|N|000|47|32|W|type:airport_region:GB-NTH|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Northamptonshire | pushpin_label = EGBK | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Northamptonshire | metric-rwy = yes | r1-number = 03R/21L | r1-length-m = 671 | r1-surface = [[Grass]] | r2-number = 05/23 | r2-length-m = 602 | r2-surface = Grass | r3-number = 03L/21R | r3-length-m = 1,258 | r3-surface = [[Concrete]] | footnotes = Sources: UK [[Aeronautical Information Publication|AIP]] at [[National Air Traffic Services|NATS]]<ref name="aip">{{cite web|url=http://www.nats-uk.ead-it.com/public/index.php%3Foption=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=106&Itemid=155.html|title=Northampton/Sywell - EGBK|publisher=}}</ref> }}
'''Sywell Aerodrome''' {{Airport codes|ORM|EGBK}} is the local aerodrome serving the town of [[Northampton]], [[Wellingborough]], [[Kettering]] and [[Rushden]], as well as wider Northamptonshire. The aerodrome is located {{Convert|5|NM|lk=in}} northeast of Northampton and was originally opened in 1928 on the edge of [[Sywell]] village.
The aerodrome caters for [[general aviation|private flying]], [[flight training]] and corporate flights. There is one fixed-wing flying school, one [[Ultralight aviation|microlight]] school and a helicopter school. The 1930s [[Art Deco]] hotel has bar and restaurant facilities. Aviation related industries and businesses are also located at the aerodrome.
Northampton (Sywell) Aerodrome has a [[United Kingdom Civil Aviation Authority|CAA]] Ordinary Licence (Number P496) that allows flights for the public transport of passengers or for flying instruction as authorised by the licensee (Sywell Aerodrome Limited).<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/375/srg_asd_ordinarylicences.pdf | format= PDF | publisher= [[Civil Aviation Authority (United Kingdom)|CAA]] SRG | title= Aerodrome Ordinary Licences | accessdate= 23 June 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070628053955/http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/375/srg_asd_ordinarylicences.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 28 June 2007}}</ref>
A viewing area is provided for [[Aircraft spotting|aircraft spotters]].
==Second World War== The aerodrome opened in 1928 and during the [[Second World War]] the aerodrome as RAF Sywell, was used as a training facility ([[de Havilland Tiger Moth|Tiger Moth]]s) and later an important centre for the repair of [[Vickers Wellington|Wellington bombers]] and extensive sheds from this time still remain on the site. Among World War II pilots who underwent training at Sywell were [[Pierre Clostermann]]<ref>Clostermann, Pierre. The Big Show. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2004. {{ISBN|0-297-84619-1}}, p. 15</ref> and [[Paddy Finucane]], who soloed here.
Many aerial shots for the film [[Battle of Britain (film)|''Battle of Britain'']] were taken over the airport and nearby area.
==Expansion== Since 1999, the aerodrome sought planning permission for a hard runway, which was intended to allow operations to continue over the winter, when the grass runways often become waterlogged.<ref>{{cite news |title = Plans to improve aerodrome site | work = [[BBC News]] |date = 26 April 2006 |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/northamptonshire/4937822.stm |accessdate = 24 August 2006}}</ref> The organisations STARE (Stop The Aerodrome Runway Expansion) and CPRE ([[Campaign to Protect Rural England]]) campaigned against this change, arguing that it would lead to more and larger aircraft flying over the area and disturb its "rural tranquility".<ref>{{cite news |title = £1m to sort out runway debate |work = Evening Telegraph |date = 14 August 2006 |url = http://www.ketteringtoday.co.uk/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=661&ArticleID=1695015 |accessdate = 24 August 2006 }}</ref> Permission was granted for the runway on 22 November 2007 by the [[Department for Transport]], and though campaigners vowed to fight the decision<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.northamptonchron.co.uk/news/Campaigners-fight-on-despite-Sywell39s.3513780.jp | date= 22 November 2007 | work= Northampton Chronicle & Echo | title= Campaigners fight on despite Sywell's runway approval | accessdate= 22 November 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071125071429/http://www.northamptonchron.co.uk/news/Campaigners-fight-on-despite-Sywell39s.3513780.jp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 25 November 2007}}</ref> they were unsuccessful and construction of the runway began in 2008. It opened during summer 2009 and enabled safe operations during the winter of 2009/2010 and onwards. In February 2010, the final inspection of the newly completed all-weather hard runway was carried out by the CAA who confirmed that it could be licensed for use.
== Operations == Sywell has three all-grass operational runways and a fourth all-weather concrete runway. The aerodrome's operational hours are 0900-1700 during winter and 0800-1700 during summer. The aerodrome offers an [[Flight Information Service|Aerodrome Flight Information Service]] to pilots.
[[File:AviationMuseum.JPG|thumb|left|Aviation Museum at Sywell]]
===Sywell Aviation Museum=== The aerodrome also houses the [[Sywell Aviation Museum]] dedicated to telling the wartime history of the site and the airmen that used it.
===Brooklands Flying Club=== Brooklands Flying Club<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklandsflyingclub.co.uk|title=HOME|website=HOME}}</ref> was based at Sywell, with a fleet of four [[Aero AT-3]] aircraft and a [[Cessna 172]]. The club offered training for a [[Private Pilot's Licence]] (PPL), night rating and IMC rating.
The club opened in 2005 under the same name of the previous company that had been located on the airfield. The flying school closed down at the end of 2013.<ref>{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}</ref> The club has since reopened as 2Excel Training, operated in partnership with [[2Excel Aviation]], owners of [[The Blades (aerobatic team)|The Blades]] aerobatics team, who are also based at the airfield.
===Training=== Other flight training organisations on the airfield include: *Sloane Helicopters *Flylight Airsports
===The Blades=== [[The Blades (aerobatic team)|The Blades]] aerobatic display team are based at Sywell, where their five [[Extra EA-300]] aircraft are hangared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theblades.com/Blades-corporate-homepage/Blades-corporate-site/Contact.aspx|title={title}|access-date=21 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303204154/http://www.theblades.com/Blades-corporate-homepage/Blades-corporate-site/Contact.aspx|archive-date=3 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They perform aerobatic displays at major events around the country, in Europe, and in the Middle East.<ref>{{url=http://www.theblades.com/Blades-public-homepage/Blades-public-site/About/The-Display.aspx}}</ref> The team is the only one fully licensed by the CAA to carry paying 'passengers' in aerobatic displays, out of Sywell, or at many other locations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theblades.com/Blades-public-homepage/Blades-public-site/Fly-with-The-Blades.aspx|title={title}|access-date=21 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160707002828/http://www.theblades.com/Blades-public-homepage/Blades-public-site/Fly-with-The-Blades.aspx|archive-date=7 July 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Sywell Airshow=== The aerodrome now hosts a bi-annual charity airshow<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sywellairshow.co.uk|title=Sywell Airshow|first=Handmade by Machine|last=Ltd|website=www.sywellairshow.co.uk}}</ref> in aid of the local [[Air Ambulance]] where there are many classic aircraft flying and on display such as the [[PBY Catalina|Catalina]], Mustang, [[T-6 Texan|North American Harvards]].
===Light Aircraft Association Rally=== The [[Light Aircraft Association]] (LAA - formerly the Popular Flying Association), is the UK's body for amateur aircraft construction, and recreational and sport flying. It used to hold its annual rally at [[Cranfield Airport]], and then at [[Kemble Airport]]. In 2006, the LAA lost so much money through poor attendances resulting from poor weather that in 2007 and 2008, much smaller (and cheaper) "regional rallies" were held. These were unpopular and in September 2009 a revived (if cut-down) LAA Rally was held at Sywell. This proved successful, and as further well-attended rallies took place at Sywell since<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aviatoruk.ga/sywell-aerodrome/|title=Sywell Aerodrome EGBK/ORM - AviatorUK|publisher=|date=2017-09-09}}</ref>, the long-term future of the LAA Rally seems secure.
===Music in Flight=== [[Music in Flight]] is an airshow held at Sywell, in which an orchestra plays [[classical music]] to accompany flying aircraft, [[hot air balloon]]s, the [[Red Devils (Parachute Regiment)|Red Devils]] parachute display team and a fireworks display.
==Business park== An industrial area in the complex accommodates firms, agencies and other commercial businesses.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category}}
*[http://www.sywellaerodrome.co.uk/ Sywell Aerodrome] - official website *[http://www.sywellaerodrome.co.uk/museum.php Sywell Aviation Museum]
{{BC Wellingborough}}
